metadata.title: Convert Miles per Gallon (UK) to Miles per Gallon (US)
metadata.description: One-step unit conversion from Miles per Gallon (UK, imperial) to Miles per Gallon (US). Includes exact conversion factor, examples, glossary, and accuracy guidance referencing measurement standards.

introduction: This tool converts fuel economy expressed in Miles per Gallon using the United Kingdom (imperial) gallon to the equivalent Miles per Gallon using the United States (US) gallon. It performs a direct unit conversion using the internationally defined gallon-to-litre values so a single numeric input produces a single converted output.

The converter presents the exact conversion factor and common rounded values, practical examples, and guidance on numerical precision and traceability. For engineering or regulatory use, read the accuracy notes and citations to relevant measurement standards.
methodology: Conversion is performed by converting both gallon definitions to litres and applying the ratio of litres per imperial gallon to litres per US gallon. This uses the internationally recognized litre definitions and gallon volume specifications published by national standards organizations.

For traceability and measurement best practice we reference standards and guidelines from NIST, ISO and other technical authorities. Results are numeric conversions only and do not attempt to estimate vehicle test-cycle fuel economy or account for measurement uncertainty beyond stated rounding guidance.
how_is_calculated: Step 1: Use the exact volumetric definitions: 1 imperial (UK) gallon = 4.54609 litres; 1 US gallon = 3.785411784 litres.
Step 2: Compute the ratio R = litres per UK gallon ÷ litres per US gallon = 4.54609 ÷ 3.785411784 ≈ 1.200949925.
Step 3: Multiply the input mpg(UK) by R to get mpg(US): mpg(US) = mpg(UK) × 1.200949925. For reverse conversion: mpg(UK) = mpg(US) ÷ 1.200949925.

Rounding: present interactive results with at least three significant digits by default and allow display to be increased to six significant digits for engineering use. Note that final displayed precision does not change the underlying converted value.
examples: Example 1: 40.0 mpg (UK) → 40.0 × 1.200949925 = 48.037997 mpg (US) → display as 48.038 mpg (US) when rounded to three decimal places.
Example 2: 50 mpg (UK) → 50 × 1.200949925 = 60.047496 mpg (US) → display as 60.047 mpg (US) when rounded to three decimal places.
Example 3 (reverse): 30 mpg (US) → 30 ÷ 1.200949925 = 24.977 mpg (UK) → display as 24.977 mpg (UK) when rounded to three decimal places.

faqs.question: Which gallon definitions are used for UK and US mpg?
faqs.answer: The converter uses the imperial gallon (UK) defined as 4.54609 litres and the US gallon defined as 3.785411784 litres. These volumetric definitions are the basis for the exact conversion ratio.

faqs.question: How accurate is the conversion and how should I round results?
faqs.answer: Calculation uses exact published litre values; the conversion factor is approximately 1.200949925. For most consumer uses, rounding to three significant digits is sufficient. For engineering, regulatory, or reporting purposes follow the precision rules required by the applicable standard or agency and include measurement uncertainty where required.

faqs.question: Does this tool account for vehicle test cycles or real-world fuel economy variability?
faqs.answer: No. This tool performs only a unit-to-unit conversion of a numeric fuel-economy value. It does not adjust for test-cycle differences, measurement bias, or real-world driving conditions. For regulatory comparisons, consult testing protocols from the relevant authority.

faqs.question: Can I convert in the opposite direction (US to UK)?
faqs.answer: Yes. Use the reciprocal of the factor: mpg(UK) = mpg(US) ÷ 1.200949925. Many UIs provide a flip control to swap fromUnit and toUnit.

faqs.question: What standards and organisations support the conversion and measurement practices?
faqs.answer: Unit definitions and measurement traceability are maintained by national and international standards bodies including NIST and ISO. Good measurement and reporting practices are recommended by technical organisations such as IEEE and occupational safety guidance from agencies like OSHA where applicable to testing environments.

faqs.question: Are there limits or invalid inputs I should be aware of?
faqs.answer: Inputs must be finite non-negative numbers. Very large inputs should be validated by your application to avoid overflow. A zero input yields zero output. Negative values are not meaningful for fuel economy and should be rejected or handled per your data validation policy.

glossary.definition: Miles per imperial gallon; fuel economy measured using the imperial (UK) gallon defined as exactly 4.54609 litres.
Miles per US gallon; fuel economy measured using the US gallon defined as exactly 3.785411784 litres.
Unit of volume used in the United Kingdom and some other countries; 1 imperial gallon = 4.54609 litres.
Unit of volume used in the United States; 1 US gallon = 3.785411784 litres.
The numeric ratio used to convert mpg(UK) to mpg(US): 4.54609 ÷ 3.785411784 ≈ 1.200949925.
